div.div: Gov. Lamont: Schools will stay closed for coronavirus until at least May 20

div.p: The possible reopening of public schools has been pushed back a full month until May 20, but state education officials have plans in motion to abandon the buildings and keep long-distance learning through the normal end of the term in June.

Gov. Ned Lamont first let the word slip out during an early afternoon conference call with small business owners, and state Education Commissioner Miguel A. Cardona explained the plans further a few hours later.
Cardona promised high school seniors that they deserve and will get some kind of graduation ceremonies, even if they are postponed until it is safer.
While many people would like to return to business as usual as soon as possible, the coronavirus threat will linger, the governor said.

“We’ll see if we have any room between then and the end of June,” Lamont said during his afternoon news briefing in the State Capitol. “That does not mean that education is stopped. Nothing would have made me happier than to be able to open up the schools sooner.”

Cardona, addressing the 530,000 students with Lamont, said that the safety of students is of paramount importance. “Please remain hopeful,” he said. “While the future seems uncertain right now, together we will emerge from this crisis and we’ll gradually resume some normalcy in both our daily lives and in the delivery of your education.”
He said that in the days before May 20, a re-evaluation of the public health issues will occur.

“This decision has not been made lightly,” Cardona said. “And it helps protect the valuable lives of not only our students, but of our dedicated staff and the hero health care workers that are working really hard to try to keep us healthy. If students are sent to school prematurely, we could be sending them into harm’s way. We know we may need to cancel classes for the remainder of the year and while we’re not announcing that today, we are planning for the worst-case scenario.”
Cardona singled out teachers throughout the state for their dedication and understands their eagerness to meet students back in the classroom.

“With a greater sense of urgency and passion for equity and access we will continue to educate,” he said, praising districts including Ansonia and New Haven for creating written packages of course materials for kids without access to computers.

Donald E. Williams Jr., executive director of the Connecticut Education Association, the teachers’ union, said that plans have been active and cooperation with administrators and state officials has been very good during the school shutdown.
“We take out cues from the health care professionals,” Williams said in a phone interview. “If schools close for the rest of the year, teachers are preparing for that circumstance.”
In Shelton, interim School Superintendent Beth Smith said there will be some type of commencement celebration for the graduating seniors.

“The students deserve that, and I look forward to celebrating with them in a safe manner when the time is right,” said Smith, stressing that schools will continue distance learning, and decisions regarding grading, exams and community service will be forthcoming.

em.p: Brian Gioiele contributed to this report.
